item.title: Biased Estimators - Ridge and Lasso regressions
item.author: Author
item.description: true library(knitr) library(captioner) fig_nums <- captioner() cod_nums <- captioner( prefix = "Code" ) Some days ago I wrote some notes concerning unbiased estimators, that are the estimators that we commonly use with linear models, and statistical analyses such as ANOVA, linear regression, etcâ€¦ Unbiased estimators try to estimate the best unknown but not casual, \(\beta\) coefficients of the independent variables (i.v.) to explain the observed dependent variable \(y\) (d.

item.title: The estimation of the unknown coefficients of a linear model by means of unbiased estimators
item.author: Author
item.description: true Linear regression is not tricky, basically, we are trying to estimate a line that efficiently interpolates our data. The focus of this page is to understand how the coefficients of a linear model are estimated by means of unbiased estimators. An unbiased estimator algorithm tries to find the best coefficients able to interpolate your current sample of data. In this case, the word bias has no relation with the notion of cognitive biases.

item.title: New R package on github! *bmscstan*: Bayesian Multilevel Single Case models
item.author: Author
item.description:
The version 1.0.0 of the package bmscstan is ready to use!

Its purpose is to provide a general, simple interface to analyse single case studies with an lme4-like syntax.

You can find it on my github page, https://github.com/michelescandola/bmscstan, and you can install it by typing in the R console devtools::install_github(michelescandola/bmscstan).
